TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as you would remember, when last we were discussing this issue I was talking in finality in my speech about taxation reform.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask the Leader of the House (Mr Young) whether he could identify the way of this morning's proceedings. I understood we were immediately going to start on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill.
—Be patient.
—I am always patient but could the Minister please explain.
—Shortly. You have a very competent government. Just be patient.
—Order! The Leader of the House has answered that it will be introduced shortly. I call the honourable member for Perth.

—As I mentioned, when the debate was interrupted on Monday I was discussing the Government's proposals for taxation reform. During the election campaign this issue was very heavily canvassed throughout the electorate and the Government at the time enunciated a nine-point tax review plan. I believe that the principles of that nine-point proposal should be expounded today in this House. The first of those was that there be no increase in the overall tax burden as measured as a share of Commonwealth tax revenue in gross domestic product. The second of the principles enunciated by the Australian Labor Party during the election campaign was that we continue the process which had been begun by this Government to provide further cuts in personal income tax. I think that is something that would be endorsed by all members of this place. The third principle was that the suggested taxation changes contribute to the smashing of tax avoidance and evasion, and that is something that is being pursued very thoroughly by all members on this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth and fifth principles were that the system which was to be instituted be simple, fairer and indeed much more progressive than that which we presently find ourselves with. The sixth principle was that the suggested tax reform not disadvantage the recipients of welfare and reduce and remove poverty tracts. The seventh principle, and perhaps one of the most important, was that it is important that in any reform package which includes indirect taxes interested groups in the community have an opportunity to respond so that there should be no regressive nature in that tax package. The eighth principle was that we provide the best possible climate for investment growth and employment. I think it is understood by both sides of the House that the incentive aspects of the tax policy are very important.

The latest aspect of our proposal was that whatever program and package we came up with there should be widespread community support for it. Indeed, in this regard we see the sharp contrast between the Opposition and ourselves. The Opposition for a long time, as it did during the election campaign, has tried to exclude a number of options. Indeed, members of the Opposition, in their very narrow way, believe that tax should be determined as they see it and that the Australian community should not be given the opportunity to have a say in this issue. When one looks at the Opposition's record on tax the dishonesty of these people-the free traders, the deregulators and the champions of enterprise-can be firmly established. They are the people who, in 1977, offered a fistful of dollars and then took them away. They are the people who had the opportunity, with their oil parity pricing windfall of $3 billion, to restructure taxation in this country and they did not take the opportunity. They are the people who said that they would institute indexation but could not deliver it. Indeed, under their government the taxation avoidance industry exploded in this country.

I have some sympathy for the view of honourable members opposite on retrospective taxation. But, unfortunately, when I look at the fact that they had the opportunity to act much earlier and did not take that chance, my sympathy dissolves. They did not act; they had the chance to act and they failed. It is not just me who is saying this. Indeed, the shadow Attorney-General a couple of weeks ago in Brisbane said that they had 'shirked their responsibility'. I think it would be very difficult for many members of this House to have sympathy for them when they look at their record. They cannot be believed. When one looks at presenting a balanced approach to the management of financial policy one cannot look at the record of our opponents with a great deal of sympathy. In our time in office we have endeavoured to kick-start the economy. Now that private investment has picked up, and with our acceptance of the trilogy, I believe this Government is committed to expenditure restraint. We are committed to funding those policies in education, housing and welfare which must not be ignored. Indeed, we are committed to a policy that will, hopefully-I feel confident about this-reverse the trend of youth unemployment which was started by our opponents.

This Government has a good record. Indeed, its record is very good. It was returned to continue its work. My colleagues and I look forward to doing so over the next three years. Our opponents may posture piously. They may endeavour, as they have done in the past, to create division and fear within the community and they may talk continually about gloom and doom, but to do so will not serve this place or the interests of Australians well. For sound economic management the Australian community will look forward to the Australian Labor Party in the future providing that sort of leadership which is most necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, firstly, I express to you my personal congratulations and the congratulations of the people I represent. I am sure that if those people were in this House they would be delighted to see you again occupying the position you occupy. The Governor-General certainly gave a detailed account and a prediction as to what would be the pattern of government by the incumbents. However, no reference was made to the debit side of the book. Life patterns of this nation which earned us the respect of the world are being dismantled.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government shall stand condemned before God and man for what has been either direct support for the many strange and sick influences that have penetrated deeply into our society or the condoning of the decimation of our standards by a blind-eye attitude. However, as to the vitality of this nation, which is so dependent on its rural industries, the hostility-indeed, the vitriolic detestation-which the majority of people in the Australian Labor Party have for those associated with rural industries has reached a point where a deep and possibly irreversible catastrophe could bring this nation and its people to their knees. No where is this more evident than in the sugar and dairy industries. Much has been said over the last few days clearly showing how destructive are the new dairy industry proposals introduced by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Government. In fact, industry spokesmen have declared loud and clear that if this plan proceeds it will virtually demolish the industry.

I turn to what could well prove to be one of Australia's most notable calamities-the decline of the sugar industry. There is a brutal attitude, almost an attitude of humour, from both the Minister for Primary Industry and our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). What did the Prime Minister say? He told the sugar farmers to go and grow vegetables. Honourable members know that that shows a deep and profound concern for this calamitous situation. I would like to impress on this House and this nation one or two basic facts relating to the people involved in the present critical situation in the sugar industry. It is a crisis for hundreds of sugar growers and those dependent on them. It could well prove to be an economic disaster for this country.

Here and now let me firmly refute statements made by misinformed people who pontificate on the alleged inefficiency of the sugar producers. I say loud and clear that although there may be the odd cane grower who has not measured up to the standard in the conduct of his farm operations, the sugar industry is respected for its high degree of efficiency and management. I have heard time and again the sugar industry being presented as an example of efficiency and as an example of an industry with deep concern for its own members and those dependent on them. The important fact is that it shows deep concern for those who are dependent on it. When we had the great crisis in the wool and cattle industries wool and cattle farmers asked: 'Why haven't we got a similar efficient organisation such as the sugar industry has?'

The sugar industry is respected for its high degree of efficiency and management, not only here in Australia; it also has a splendid reputation overseas where it is frequently quoted as an example of industry efficiency and management at its best. The Australian sugar industry is located principally along the coast of Queensland and on the northern coast of New South Wales. Currently there are 29 sugar milling districts in Queensland and three in northern New South Wales. The Queensland sugar district is serviced by the relatively large centres of Cairns, Innisfail, Tully, Ingham, Burdekin, Proserpine, Mackay, Bundaberg and Nambour. I do not like to go into statistics; in fact, I totally detest reading a speech, but some of these basic facts are important. I mention those towns because the lights could well go out in those towns. They could face an immeasurable crisis.

In 1984 Queensland harvested 24 million tonnes of cane for a sugar make of 3.3m tonnes. The three New South Wales areas harvested 1.6 million tonnes of cane for 200,000 tonnes of sugar. Over the last 20 years the Australian industry has increased its peak production targets from 1.33 million tonnes to around 3.3 million tonnes of sugar, an increase of some 150 per cent. From that encouraging, exhilarating situation we have the gloomy situation that exists today. This achievement resulted in more settlement and added resources in north Queensland coastal areas which meant that the whole of Australia began to vibrate more because of the activities of this industry. It meant valuable export earnings for all Australians. Production to mid-1960 was safely covered by price and outlet with supply to the domestic market and other countries under the British Commonwealth Sugar Agreement. The industry expanded in mid-1960 and began to supply other world markets, in particular Japan, Europe and the United States of America which meant the introduction of a large number of new growers. Again, this was an exciting development. Some of those farmers have gone, some are still with us. At the end of 1960 there was a brief but significant collapse in price. The price dropped as low as $125 a tonne. Things were very different in those days-$125 was not too bad. This required the industry to provide loan funds to be repaid over 10 years at an all up repayment and interest cost of $30m. The industry further expanded in the mid-1970s to cater for increased operations and overseas sales. There was a sudden fall off in price in the latter part of the 1970s, quickly followed by a reverse cycle with very high prices in 1980 and 1981.

These dry old statistics I am quoting have a target. They indicate that there has been a rise and fall, that there have been gloomy times, but they have recovered. They have recovered because there was a government in office that was determined that they should recover. That government had an intense desire to set this industry back in business. A further limited expansion took place in 1981, with most areas increasing production in 1981 and into 1982.

It is so far a fairly rosy story. Then came the European Economic Community and changes in the world profit of sugar. They say that a four-letter word is about the ugliest word we come into contact with, but when we see the very vitals of our rural industries in Australia being decimated, I think the ugliest word around is EEC. The EEC, since the late 1970s when it was a net importer, has become a large exporter of around four million plus tonnes of sugar. This resulted from the high subsidisation of its production under its common agricultural policy. In 1984 the subsidy was $1100m, or $500 per tonne of sugar. The free market price was $104 per tonne.

Two lesser importing countries have increased production to provide for self-sufficiency. There is an oversupply in the free world market. As a consequence of this oversupply the world free market sugar price plummeted, with a drop of 70 per cent in the 1980 to 1984 period. Home consumption sales are the same now as 10 years ago. There has been some loss in recent times due to the anti-sugar attitude.

I will discuss that anti-sugar attitude now. I recently decided I would have a thorough check up. I think we all do that from time to time. I attended a very, very reputable doctor, although I will not mention his name for ethical reasons. He said: 'Look, I would like to tell the people of Australia that this anti-sugar nonsense should cease and cease immediately. Everything, if you do not take it in moderation, causes problems, but take this anti-sugar attitude. Everything you look at these days is labelled ''no sugar added''. In many cases the fact that there is no sugar added is detrimental to the health of our people'.

Home consumption sales are the same as 10 years ago. Export markets are now at 80 per cent of Australian production. The International Sugar Agreement negotiations failed in June 1984. We had no John McEwen or Doug Anthony over there, so they failed. They failed as far as Australia is concerned because there was not that intense desire to see a great industry survive, to see international agreement orientated to our other trade associations with the likes of Japan. What did John McEwen say years ago? He said: 'Okay, if you are going to insist on this sugar agreement, which disadvantages my country, we do not really need to bring Japanese cars to our country. We will have a look at the whole thing when I get back home.' Within 24 hours the agreement was renegotiated to our advantage. That is the sort of intense and determined attitude which must permeate these international discussions if they are going to be effective.

Related to the average sugar content in cane, the 1981 high would have given a cane price of $24.18. The projected price for 1986 is a cane price to the grower of $15.29 per tonne at that level of sugar-a drop of 27 per cent. The situation, when one examines these figures, boils down to the fact that an abundance of sugar at low prices is available. The industry has attempted to counter the problems by containing costs as best it can. I make this point clearly and decisively: People in rural industries, whether it be the tobacco industry, the cattle industry, the wool industry-these great industries on which Australia permanently depends; not the come and go industries but the industries which are producing all the time-cannot control their costs. If a shirt manufacturer's costs increase he can add $1, $2 or whatever to the price of his shirts. However, it is not possible to increase prices in the rural industries. They are at the mercy of international agreements and demands. So the story goes.

Sugar producers provide Australian consumers with a continuous and ample supply at more than competitive prices. The industry subsidises when prices are high, and the consumer when prices are low. Has the industry earned government support?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Of course it has. The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir, says: 'Yes'. It is a decisive yes. These people, like so many other people in rural industries, have contributed in areas where one sweats one's guts out. This applies to most of our rural industries. The sugar industry has contributed vastly to Australia's economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue I wish to address is the proposal for tax reform. As a representative from an electorate which currently contributes more per capita to the taxation coffers than does any other electorate in Australia, I, and the electors of Canberra, welcome this long-awaited reform of the taxation system. The people of Canberra mainly are public servants, all pay as you earn taxpayers, so they are the ones who have been bearing the brunt of the taxation contribution over the years. So, we welcome this reform.

However, in the few moments I have to address this issue, I want to refer to the impact of tax reform on women. Women have much to gain from tax reform which improves equity and efficiency. Women are dependent on government services and assistance to a much greater extent than are men. A taxation system that is inefficient fails to provide revenue for an adequate level of such services. Even in the context of not increasing the overall tax burden, a tax system which enables efficient collection of tax from those in a position to pay allows for a much fairer distribution of the tax burden, to the advantage of women.

It is essential on equity and efficiency criteria that the individual remain the unit for personal income tax. This is the trend in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and it is based on sound reasons. For example, where the earned income of spouses is aggregated for tax purposes, it imposes very high tax rates on secondary earners, usually women. The individual unit also avoids the problems associated with defining the household for taxation purposes. That is difficult, as only 20 per cent of Australian households currently comprise single income couples with dependent children. Also, empirical studies from overseas indicate that family unit tax discourages married women from entering the work force. However, while Australia retains the individual as the basic unit of tax, income splitting remains a major problem, especially as a result of the High Court of Australia decision in the Everett case in 1980. This problem must be addressed when we are looking at any tax reform package.

One issue that has received attention in the tax debate is that of tax deductibility for child care. I do not support this because it would create its own problems in terms of equity, efficiency and effective redistribution. It would be more appropriate to direct resources into support for the children's services program, which is moving quickly towards the Government's promise of 20,000 new child care places in the next three years. Every child who secures a place in a Commonwealth funded child care system receives a subsidy of between $1,560 and $2,080 per annum. In addition, the Government has a system of fee relief for those on low incomes. I feel that is a much more efficient way of administering the taxation dollar. In other words, the Government is working towards the provision of affordable high quality child care. We may debate in this House whether we are moving quickly enough towards that. I am sure everyone in this House would want more facilities available for child care throughout Australia, but I do not think the way to do that is to have tax deductibility for child care.

The Governor-General, in his Speech, stated that the raising of the status of women in all parts of our society would remain at the forefront of the Government's policy objectives. I suggest that one excellent way of raising the status of women is through reform of the taxation system, with special reference to the special needs of women. I thank the House.

They make me realise how we can tend to overexaggerate the benefits of our society. Such situations can very easily emotionally blind wise judgments. I intend to carry out my duties with a feeling of responsibility but with a sense of proportion. I believe one should have a passionate devotion to a cause, but I am aware that unless that passion is guided by a sense of responsibility it can be wasteful and indeed harmful to society.

I said then that I was idealistic but I hoped that my stay in the House would not breed that cynicism which had become prevalent of late. I suppose those words are equally true some nine years later. I suppose too that that is my sense of responsibility and my sense of dedication to the job ahead of me in representing the people of Fadden. There is no doubt that in our society there are some very great worries. In the electorate of Fadden, as across Australia, there is no doubt that the assets test is still causing some very great difficulties for the aged. It is interesting to note that some 50,000 of our aged are now suffering the effects of that assets test. One would hope that the Government would show some more compassion to those people who have worked hard and made sure that they saved for their old age. They should not now be penalised and put in this situation that they face.

There are other areas too. The whole issue of taxation, which is the subject of wide-ranging debate across our society, is another matter which I think is of concern to all Australians, but most particularly to those middle income Australians, the young married couples who have children, who are working hard to make sure that their family receives the best. One hopes that any changes in the taxation system will bring in that sense of equity for those people who are really the backbone of Australia, who are working so hard to bring up their families in an environment which we should all be able to enjoy.

During the last 20 months I have worked in the tourist industry. It was interesting to hear the maiden speeches of the new members of this Parliament because most of them referred to the tourist attractions in their electorates. It is interesting now to reflect on the situation in 1975 in this House, when even the Treasury did not acknowledge tourism as an industry in itself. I am glad that that attitude has changed, inasmuch as there is a recognition abroad in our community that tourism is very much a major industry, an industry which in fact is bigger than the footwear, clothing and motor vehicle industries combined. It is contributing to the gross domestic product as much as the mining industry and is, in fact, fast becoming the greatest employer in this nation.

That latter point is a very salient one because at a time when we are spending some very large amounts of money on Commonwealth employment programs it is interesting to see that it is tourism more than any other industry that has the capacity to provide, and is providing, real jobs rather than artificial jobs in our community. In my home State of Queensland at the moment there are no fewer than 92,000 people working in the tourist industry. That is more than double the figure of just five years ago. That will give honourable members an indication of the potential we have to provide meaningful jobs for the whole spectrum of our society. Jobs for young people, for the old and for women are all in that industry if we get it right. Successive governments, going back to the time when Sir Phillip Lynch was Minister responsible, have gradually been looking at the aspects of tourism which can help in an employment sense. I think this Government should be congratulated for the amount of money it is spending in promoting tourism to Australia. But I also think it should be very careful to get the format right and make sure the money it spends overseas is spent wisely. It will be interesting to see what the real result of the Paul Hogan campaign is when the figures are released a little later this year. It is true that we have spent many millions of dollars in the United States of America on promoting Australia as a destination. It is true that there have been literally hundreds of thousands of inquiries by residents of the United States wanting to visit Australia, but the proof will certainly be in the pudding; the proof will be if those people actually come.

I worry about some of the aspects of the operation of the Australian Tourist Commission because it seems evident to me that maybe we are not really getting the real results we should out of spending so much money on such a campaign. For example, most of that money was spent in the area of California and the rest of the West Coast of the United States. That area has always been a prime tourist market, especially for northern Europe and South America. But if honourable members look at the figures, the biggest potential market Australia has is the central west of the United States. It is there where the biggest money is, it is there where the Australian Tourist Commission is not represented and it is there that we frankly have not spent a brass razoo. I think we should be looking at the operations of the Australian Tourist Commission to make sure we cover all those areas.

If we look at the expenditure pattern of international tourists I wonder whether the Australian Tourist Commission has done the right thing in projecting so much of its concentration into that North American market. The latest figures I have available indicate that the average Australian resident tourist travelling around Australia spends about $34 per head, per day. The New Zealanders are still our biggest market and they spend about $43 per head per day. The Americans come in at $68 per head per day. But if we look at, for example, the Japanese market, the average expenditure of a Japanese tourist in Australia at the moment is $79.91 per head per day.

If one starts looking into the northern European market one sees that the Scandinavians spend $92 per head per day, the Swiss spend $94 per head per day, and the West German tourists spend a massive $136 per head per day while in Australia. Yet, for some reason this year the Australian Tourist Commission has actually cut the amount of money that is being spent on promoting Australia in northern Europe. It is very important that that concentration remain on northern Europe, because it will be northern European tourists who will use very much the infrastructure of the Australian industry. For example, an American who is coming to Australia might have his McDonalds hamburgers and a Coke for lunch. On the other hand, the German would tend to use restaurants for both lunch and dinner. It is in those areas that we do have a very great capacity to employ so many young people today. It is in the hospitality industry and the restaurant and catering industry that so many of those jobs will be provided.

I think it is important that the Australian Tourist Commission get its emphasis right. In my home State of Queensland in the last 12 to 18 months we have seen a massive explosion in the number of Japanese tourists who are coming to Australia. We read regularly in the Press that the Japanese see Australia as one of their prime destinations. It is one of the places that they want to visit. Yet there are some great difficulties because the amount of capacity provided by the international airlines on the Japan-Australia run is limited. Although at the end of this month an additional service will be provided, it will still not be enough to be able to provide the number of seats that are required if we are really going to be involved in that Japanese international tourism market. I think Australia has been wise inasmuch as it has concentrated its efforts in that Japanese market on young people. It is true that the Japanese are probably the hardest tourists to look after. But the young Japanese people now have a knowledge of English. They do not require to go around the countryside in organised groups. The other thing--

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of them come here for honeymoons.

—Many of them come here for honeymoons. That is the point I was going to raise. The Japanese honeymoon market is probably one of the most lucrative that we can get into. According to Japanese tradition, the honeymooners have an obligation to buy a gift for those people who come to their wedding. They usually buy their gifts at their point of destination. So in terms of the souvenir industry in Australia a lot of money is to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: We should be making sure that we can provide the capacity for the Japanese to come to Australia-that is, airline seats. If we do not do that we will certainly miss out on a big potential market. I bring that point forward because in recent days the Premier of Queensland, who has just returned from Japan, has made an announcement that he has the application by All Nippon Airways for charter flight rights into north Queensland and Brisbane. One would hope that the Government in its wisdom will see fit to grant those charter rights as soon as possible, because that is a huge market. If one is looking at a return airfare between Australia and Japan of under $500-that is really what the charter market is all about, fixing those fares so that international visitors can come here-I am sure that we will see a massive explosion of the whole tourist industry in north Queensland. I think the Government should be concentrating very closely indeed on that charter concept in this time of talk of deregulation in so many other areas.

Already there has been initial interest in European charter operators coming to Australia providing a fare of about $850 return from Europe. If one lines up that fare against those being offered by the scheduled operators one can see that while the schedule fares remain in place we may not be very competitive. But if we can get those low priced international charter air fares into operation the tyranny of distance, which has for so long been one of the big difficulties in building the international tourist market for Australia, can be overcome. It is a fact that the Europeans and the Japanese are travelling further and further these days to reach their tourist destinations. It is just the cost of the air fare which will stop them coming to Australia.

When we talk about deregulation I must also say that I was very pleased indeed to see that the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) announced yet another review of the two-airline system in Australia. Despite what Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines tell us, this country still has the highest domestic air fare structure in the world. The airlines can argue until they are blue in the face but the plain facts of the situation are that in all the overseas countries so many fares are available which allow tourists to get around that when one stacks up against them the around Australia fare of $800 one sees that the cost of internal travel in Australia, especially for international visitors, is a real deterrent. One would hope for some breaking of the regulated mould that we have now in order to allow real tourist fares, or even charter fares, within Australia to be made available to both the international and domestic markets.

One of my jobs when I was out of this place over the last 20 months was, in fact, to negotiate on international air rights and to have discussions with the domestic airlines regarding the whole situation of rights and fare structures. It was interesting at one stage that the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation, where I was working, in fact put together with East West Airlines Ltd a charter air fare from Sydney to the Gold Coast at a cost of $99 return. We put with that a $100 a week accommodation package which meant that people travelling out of Sydney at least could go for a holiday on the Gold Coast for less than $200 for a week. That was very popular until the two major domestic airlines decided to come in on top of East West Airlines and literally knock it off the route. I think that is the sort of situation we have to get over. We can start looking at charter air fares within Australia in the range of, say, $200 from Sydney to Cairns and back, and $250 from Melbourne to Cairns and back, not operating against scheduled services, but operating in off hours purely as tourist charters.

I believe that for the health of the nation, as much as anything else, we should try to encourage people to travel around Australia. In the last two years something like 46 per cent of the population has not been away from home, has not had a holiday. I think we should do whatever we can, not only for the purpose of providing extra employment in the tourist industry but also for the health of people, to encourage people to move around to see what this tremendous country has to offer in terms of tourist attractions. Australia is one of the greatest countries in that respect. Most importantly, we should make sure that we can get some of those people out of the environment which I mentioned in that quotation from the original maiden speech. If we can get that extra 46 per cent of the population to move around we will find, in fact, that many of our unemployment problems will be overcome.

It is interesting that the Bureau of Industry Economics indicates in its figures that every time we have a net increase of 25,000 international visitors to Australia we create another 1,200 jobs. Every time we can get an Australian to go on holidays we can start cranking up that employment generator as well. Every time we can get 230 people to get in their cars, drive across a State border and take a holiday of at least one night we create a job. When we can get that net number increased we will create more jobs. Tourism, more than any other industry in Australia today, has the capacity to be able to provide that long term employment.

I hope that in future Budget considerations the Government will look at not only increasing the amount of money allocated to the Australian Tourist Commission for overseas promotion but also furthering its endeavours in promoting domestic tourism in Australia. Both factors are very real in terms of the employment that they can create in this industry, an industry which is now the second biggest in Queensland. In terms of the amount of money it brought into the State, it beat the sugar industry last year. It is the biggest employer in Queensland. Those figures are certainly starting to be reflected around the other States of Australia. But that is not to say that I am criticising the Government at all. What I am saying is that it should get its priorities right in terms of the money it provides for employment generation and that the tourist industry, more than any other industry, has that capacity to be able to provide so much of that long term employment rather than some of the artificial programs on which millions and millions of dollars are being spent today. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has come into the House. I am sure that he heard my words of wisdom when he was in his office and had to run to the House to hear exactly what I was going to say.

I think another aspect that we should be looking at is making sure that when the Minister looks, for example, at the operations of the Australian Tourist Commission he makes sure that we have a lean, hard body which has the commercial capacity to get into those overseas market-places and promote Australia in a very real way. My suggestion to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism who is at the table is simply this: Maybe it is time for the charter of the Australian Tourist Commission to be overhauled and looked at to ensure that when its representatives are overseas promoting Australia they can also deliver the goods. I think the Commission does a pretty good job of straight promotion but in terms of the commercial side, of really putting together the tourist packages to make sure those tourists can get here, I think that under its present charter the ATC is lacking. I think we should perhaps be looking to making it a more commercial entity.

I think it is worth repeating that every time we can get an additional 25,000 international visitors to this country we create another 1,200 jobs. Every time we get an additional 230 people in Australia taking a domestic holiday we have another job up. My only hope is that there will be a realisation in the Government and, indeed, throughout the community that it is the tourist industry more than any other that we must promote. We must make sure that that industry provides jobs for this generation of Australians and for generations to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about rock and roll?

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

SPEECH.PARA: Although Board funds now and in the past go primarily to the support of 'fine music',--

The question to be asked is how equitable these allocations are. It seems that we are favouring a system of double standards. The present funding arrangements could be seen as favouring one age group against another, one income group against another, and a minority against a majority. Two interesting examples of this are the amounts of money that people pay to see these various types of performances. When the mink coat and sable set file into the Sydney Opera House and put their bottoms on the seats, the Government has already put $45 on each seat before they sit down. When the kids go to the Sydney Entertainment Centre it is full cost recovery there. When they go to the Entertainment Centre to see such great entertainers as Bruce Springsteen and the other acts which have been on recently, everyone pays full price. The opera company itself has great difficulty keeping going, despite the massive subsidies the Government gives it. Honourable members would have read in the newspapers recently that the Australian Opera was on the financial brink. It was thinking of putting itself into receivership. When one has a look at its administration, one wonders what is going on. I read in the newspaper the other day that it inadvertently paid $1m in payroll tax that it did not have to pay because it is a tax exempt body. It caters for sporting events, ballet and opera performances, rock, ethnic and pensioner concerts. Most of the concerts that are held there are sellouts.

I think there are two conclusions that can be drawn from these facts. The current Government funding overwhelmingly favours what are termed fine musical tastes for a comparative few. The popular musical tastes of the large proportion of Australians are apparently neglected or receive token treatment. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only one thing is sure, and that is that the Government is going to be rock and rolled at the next election. Just 14 months ago this Government sold to the public the idea that on the payment of the Medicare levy all Australians would have access to medical and hospital cover. The Government argued that Medicare would provide all Australians with equal and guaranteed access to quality health care. Medicare was to provide all the answers, and people were led to believe that there was no need to maintain private health insurance. In fact, the community was actively discouraged from maintaining private health insurance. Economic pressure was applied by the Government to ensure that people gave up their private insurance. The Government removed the tax rebate which previously applied to health insurance premiums. The cost of health insurance premiums was pushed up by the Government's removal of $80 of assistance to health funds for long term patients. To hasten further the death of health insurance funds the Government also prohibited medical insurance in a number of areas, most notably by prohibiting gap insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the economic pressure there was also a slick advertising campaign, together with blatantly misleading promotional material. For example, a pamphlet 'About Medicare. I was wondering . . .' states:
Question: How is Medicare paid for? Answer: Medicare is to be funded by a one per cent levy on taxable income.

That, of course, is a total and absolute fabrication. It is a blatant lie. It was clearly part of a deliberate strategy undertaken by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to mislead and confuse the Australian public. Just how big a lie was it? The full-year cost of Medicare at the time was estimated to be $1,790m. After five months operation the cost of a full year of operation of Medicare blew out to $2,050m. So the cost of Medicare this year is estimated in the Budget to be $2,050m. What is the levy going to raise? According to the Budget, the Medicare levy is to raise around $1,200m, or $850m short of the cost of Medicare. Yet, the Minister, through his pamphlets, said that the levy was going to fund Medicare. It is $850m short of funding Medicare-an $850m fib.

As a result of the Government's deliberately misleading advertising and the economic pressures applied by the Government, hundreds of thousands of Australians who had traditionally exercised freedom of choice to take out private insurance, encouraged by the sweeping promises in respect of Medicare, dropped their insurance and turned to the public sector. The voters were promised and misled into thinking that what they were getting was a national health insurance scheme. What they got was a national health service. A national health insurance scheme implies universality of cover. However, by definition, universality of cover does not automatically lead to a shift of health care from the private sector to the public sector. Yet, that is exactly what is occurring. It is happening because we have a national health service, not a national health insurance scheme.

There is nothing implicit in the concept of universality of cover which requires that people lose their choice of doctor, lose their choice of hospital or, for that matter, lose their choice of insurer. The Government's real intention has not been to give universal cover. That was the smokescreen. Rather, it is out to nationalise health. The problem is that honourable members opposite have accepted the misleading advice from the Goebbels of the Health portfolio, the Minister for Health.

Is section 17 of the health legislation, which is concerned with the controlling of doctors' contracts in hospitals, essential for a universal health insurance scheme? Of course it is not. The provisions of section 17 can be understood only in the context of socialised medicine where the employment of doctors is under the control of the Government, not the patient.

The categorisation of private hospitals and the classification and regulation of private hospitals, as are occurring under Medicare, are designed to bring private hospitals into the public sector. There is no purpose in strangling the private hospital system other than to convert all hospitals into public facilities. That is not necessary in a system of universal health insurance cover.

If bulk billing is carried out to the extent that this Government is pushing, it will result in doctors becoming employees of the Government rather than the patient. The crippling restrictions placed on private insurers, the withdrawal of rebates, the failure to ensure community rating, the prohibition of gap insurance and the withdrawal of reinsurance subsidies have all made it increasingly difficult for private insurers to play a major role in the provision of health cover.

The balance of private and public sector involvement in the delivery of health care, which has been the hallmark of the Australian system now for a number of decades, has thus been destroyed. Having fallen prey to the Government's slick and misleading selling of the Medicare package, what has been the experience after 12 months? Have all Australians in fact been provided with equal and guaranteed access to health care as promised? In Victoria the queues for major surgery have more than doubled in the last two years. This is exactly what was predicted by the Opposition. We warned that by actively discouraging people from taking out private insurance, the burden on the public hospital system would become intolerable and queues would develop. Between 15,000 and 20,000 people are now awaiting admission to hospitals in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful!

—It is disgraceful. One cannot blame the doctors for what is happening in Victoria because they are not engaged in any industrial dispute in that State. The blame has to be placed on Medicare. Victoria is not the only State in which this is happening. In South Australia, for example, the queue for ear, nose and throat surgery at the Royal Adelaide Hospital has quadrupled and there is now a 12 months delay. This is the result of Medicare. I have been flooded with examples of the hardship caused by these Medicare-generated queues. Let me quote very briefly just one. Mrs T of Victoria requires both knee joints to be replaced. She is unable to walk and is confined to bed. She has been in this situation since 3 February 1984. She has been confined to bed for over 14 months because of Dr Blewett's Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: Fundamental changes to the health care delivery system are required. The issue is not simply doctors' incomes, as the Government would like the public to believe. The underlying issue is whether Australia is to continue down the Labor Government's path of a bureaucratic, expensive nationalised health service or whether we are to rebuild and improve upon the dual system of public and private health care which has been the hallmark of Australian health care for the past century. Statements that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Health have been making recently sound exactly like the statements made during the debates of a year ago on section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. At that time the Minister for Health stated:
Nothing in Medicare threatens private medical practice in this country.

The Prime Minister's recent assurances that his Government has no intention of destroying private health practice in this country fly in the face of all the evidence. One only has to look at what is happening to the private hospital system and to the private health funds, and then weigh the pressure on consumers to leave the private sector and become public patients along with the pressures on doctors to bulk bill, to recognise that the effects of the Government's policies will be to nationalise health.

The Hawke Government also promised that Medicare would be fair and equitable, but we have seen what has happened to the poor and the elderly. They have been struck in evergrowing queues. The Government has doggedly refused to accept that the central issue in all the health-related disputes around the country is Medicare itself. As long as the Government remains unwilling to make any changes to the basic structure of Medicare, there can be little progress towards a long term settlement of these disputes. The premise that the great bulk of health care should be financed and delivered through the auspices of the Government, with doctors no longer being employed by their patients but by the Government, is fundamental to the structure of Medicare which the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health insist will not be changed. However, it is not fundamental to a system of universal health cover. Likewise the strangulation of both the private health insurers and the private hospitals is fundamental to the basic structure of Medicare, but, most emphatically, is not fundamental to a system of universal health cover.

It has become clear why the Government has not taken steps to alleviate the problems of Medicare and avoid the present crisis. We know that the Minister is a very determined left wing socialist and it is obvious that he does not want to take the necessary steps to change Medicare because he is determined to pursue his policy to its conclusion, which is the institution of socialised medicine in Australia. Instead of initiating change which could have averted the present crisis, the Government has attempted to paint the medical profession as the villain. The doctors have been holding firm for fundamental changes to Medicare because they know that under a national health system the high standard of medical care which Australians have enjoyed under the dual system of private and public care will deteriorate, and at best Australians will be left with mediocrity.

The fundamental issue which the doctors are attempting to address but which the Government will not address is whether private health care can survive in Australia. The Minister has calculated that, if the situation becomes acute enough, the doctors will have to back down and settle for short term concession rather than fundamental changes to Medicare. The Government is using as pawns those Australians who cannot afford private health insurance. The people who are genuinely dependent upon the public hospitals, those who cannot afford to turn to the private sector, are being forced to bear the brunt of this Government's reckless game of brinksmanship. The poor, the elderly, the chronically ill are the ones who are being shunted to the back of the growing queues for admission to hospital. The Government is ruthless in its pursuit of socialised medicine, and appears to be determined to win at any cost. Let me give a classic example of the disadvantages of a socialised health delivery scheme.

—These fellows would not spend in a year as much as the Minister would spend in one day of his overseas trips. In the Australian Capital Territory there are a number of health care centres which are manned by salaried medical officers. —When do they work?

—If the honourable member waits for a minute he will hear the answer. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Government has decided upon a course of action which will put to rest once and for all the extent of unauthorised telephone interception in New South Wales and the extent to which that material may disclose breaches of the law. The proposed course of action has been arrived at in consultation with the Government of New South Wales and it is a course of action on which both Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby agree.

Before coming to the details of that course of action, I would like to set the record straight on a number of matters because it has been suggested that there has been an 'about face' on the issue. I regard comments of that kind as grossly inaccurate in a context where I have been endeavouring to resolve, and I believe the Government has now resolved, a most difficult issue in the administration of criminal justice.

As is well known, Mr Justice Stewart in his eighth interim report recommended that indemnities be granted to 31 New South Wales police officers in respect of conduct which may have breached the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. Mr Justice Stewart was faced, in making that recommendation, with a difficult problem, namely, that in order to obtain truthful evidence for the officers concerned, he felt they needed to be given an assurance that they would not be prosecuted in respect of matters arising out of their evidence. I do not want to underestimate the difficulty Mr Justice Stewart faced, but his recommendations presented me with at least as much difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I am reluctant to interrupt the Attorney-General. A second reading speech has been distributed to the Parliament and I am reading it. The Attorney-General is making an entirely different speech. He is not making the second reading speech and this should be clarified.

—On the point of order, by way of clarification, it was thought there would need to be an additional statement which, or course, was given to the Opposition. I am sorry that the honourable member has not received it. I think it is available. This matter was drawn to the attention of the Leader of the House (Mr Young). I apologise if the honourable member has not received it. It was done to avoid trying to do two things separately. I am not trying to embarrass the honourable member, but the statement was given.
—My point is that it is not headed 'second reading speech'. That is the point I am making.

—On the point of order, by arrangement it was agreed to combine the two statements. I apologise if the honourable member did not know that. But it was agreed on that basis. The prosecution policy of the Commonwealth, which I emphasise was presented to the Parliament in December 1982 by the Acting Attorney-General, on behalf of the then Attorney-General, lays down very clear principles to be applied in the grant of an indemnity by the Attorney-General. I want to refer to those principles because I think they are very important in considering this matter. I quote what was said by the Attorney-General in 1982:

SPEECH.PARA: In principle it is desirable that the criminal justice system should operate without the need to grant indemnities or pardons to persons who participate in offences with a view to these persons giving evidence against the principal offenders . . .

Nevertheless, before a decision is made to grant an indemnity or to recommend to the Governor-General the grant of a pardon, all possible alternative courses must be considered. One possible alternative which must always be considered is to proceed to conviction of the prospective witness in respect of at least some of the offences committed by him before commencement of the trial of the principal offender . . .
The question is-and I quote again:
Is the evidence of the person in respect of whom the indemnity or pardon is sought essential to achieve the conviction of the principal offender?
The policy statement then concluded with these words:

The ultimate decision to grant an indemnity or recommend grant of a pardon is only made after the most careful consideration of . . (the) material. Assuming a decision is made to grant an indemnity, the scope of the indemnity should be no wider than the circumstances require.

The principles I have just referred to make it clear that indemnities should not be lightly given; and they should be given in a context where the person, the subject of the indemnity, is capable of giving evidence in a prosecution for a more serious offence than the offence the subject of the indemnity. In considering the application of these principles, I have been concerned that breaches of Commonwealth intercept law cannot be taken lightly. That law regulates intrusion into the basic privacy of every citizen. Unauthorised and illegal intrusion is a very serious matter. I add that the Government takes the gravest view of illegal intrusions on the rights of individuals, particularly by police. I quote the following statement which I have made:

The Federal Telecommunications (Interception) Act is a protection of the civil rights of the citizens of Australia. Breaches of it, particularly by police, are not matters that can be overlooked except in situations of the utmost gravity.

The advice of the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Ian Temby, QC, was sought. Mr Temby advised against the grant of indemnities and his reasoning is consistent with the principles set out in the prosecution policy of the Commonwealth which I have just described. I repeat that the evidence there was not likely to lead to the prosecution of any person. I should also add that both Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby have advised me that the Age materials themselves are unlikely to lead to prosecutions. The issues now involved, however, are much wider than the granting of indemnities to New South Wales police officers.

As I have already said in the Parliament, Mr Justice Stewart has reported on a much wider extent of unauthorised interception in New South Wales than the period of the Age materials, which was 1976 to 1981. Mr Justice Stewart refers in his report to the fact that unauthorised intercepts took place in New South Wales up to 1984. The Government believes that the time has come to have the full extent of unauthorised interception in New South Wales thoroughly examined by a royal commission. The Government believes that an independent assessment should be made of the extent to which material or information relating to unauthorised intercepts discloses offences against the law. The Government has decided to change the terms of the Stewart Royal Commission to inquire into and report upon these fundamental matters. The course of action which has been arrived at, in agreement with the Government of New South Wales, is as follows:
1. Amend the Royal Commissions Act 1923 (NSW) to provide that Stewart J. can exercise the powers of a judge of the Supreme Court under that Act.
2. Amend the Commonwealth terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission to empower that Royal Commission to inquire into and report upon-

(a) whether there exists any information or material, including documents or tape recordings, relating to unauthorised telephone intercepts occurring in New South Wales in the possession of any person-in particular, NSW police and Australian Federal Police-which discloses an offence or possible offence against a law of the Commonwealth and which warrants further investigation;
I explain that 'offence' is, of course, a criminal offence. That is the definition of 'offence' in that regard. The Royal Commission will report upon-
(b) the nature of the offence or offences so disclosed;

(c) the identity of any person who Stewart J. considers is capable of giving evidence which will or will tend to render such information or material admissible in a prosecution for an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of the State, or who is capable of giving information which might reasonably lead to evidence of such an offence, in respect of whom Stewart J. recommends an indemnity in relation to offences against Commonwealth law in connection with unauthorised telephone intercepts.
It should be noted that the grant of indemnity will be subject to the following conditions:

The person concerned gives, in the opinion of Mr Justice Stewart, his active co-operation including the giving of evidence truthfully and frankly and withholding nothing of relevance in the inquiry aforementioned in which he is required to give evidence;

Mr Justice Stewart remains satisfied at the conclusion of the inquiry that the actions of the person concerned were carried out for the sole purpose of gathering information for use only in the investigation of crime.

3. New South Wales will establish terms of reference for Stewart J. similar to the Commonwealth terms, but in respect of State offences. The proposed Commonwealth terms of reference have been discussed with the New South Wales Government and its officials.
4. Amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979:
(a) to remove the requirement that Stewart J. must establish the authenticity of the Age materials before dealing with them further;
(b) to permit persons to furnish material to the Royal Commission without breaching that Act;

(c) to permit the Royal Commission to pass on material to responsible authorities-for example, the National Crime Authority, the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Australian Federal Police, the New South Wales Police, the New South Wales Solicitor-General-without committing an offence against that Act.

I welcome the co-operation I have received from the Opposition in allowing this matter to be introduced as a matter of urgency today. Save for the authenticity question, the amendments proposed are consistent with the earlier Stewart Royal Commission amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act.

That is the proposed course of action. It has the agreement of Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby. They have been consulted on the new terms of reference for the Royal Commission. The Royal Commission, under its revised Commonwealth and New South Wales terms of reference, will be able to inquire into and report on:
(a) the full extent of unauthorised telephone interception in New South Wales.

It is not limited by any period of interception, except, I might add, that it would be limited as from today. In other words, we would not be countenancing any further interception merely because we are introducing this Bill. We emphasise that it must cease, certainly as from the establishment of this Commission.
(b) the full extent of criminal conduct exposed by that interception; and
(c) the recommendation of indemnities, but based upon proper principles.

The Royal Commission will be required to report to both governments not later than 31 December 1985. I make the point that we would expect all police officers concerned to come before the Commission within 28 days from this date. We see no need for any longer period. Anybody who has any information should come forward with that information within that period of time. If that is so, it may well be that the Commission can complete its deliberations well before 31 December next.

I move to the contents of the amending Bill. It amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 to enable Mr Justice Stewart, as Royal Commissioner, to investigate unauthorised telephone intercepts occurring in New South Wales to see whether they disclose an offence or possible offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory. The Government's decision to enlarge Mr Justice Stewart's terms of reference for this purpose was dealt with in the ministerial comments I have already made.

The Bill generally follows the form of the amendments that were passed last year at the Budget sittings to enable the so-called Age materials to be passed to Mr Justice Stewart in his capacity as Royal Commissioner appointed to inquire into drug trafficking. There are, however, two major changes which, in effect, make the inquiry envisaged by this legislation a completely new one in many respects.

First of all, the legislation will enable Mr Justice Stewart to look at material and information additional to material and information relating to the Age materials. Secondly, the Bill removes the requirement that was inserted in the legislation enacted last year to the effect that the material could only be used after an initial finding by Mr Justice Stewart that the documents in question are an authentic record of the matters purported to be recorded in them. Mr Justice Stewart has agreed that this requirement should be removed, having regard to the unreliable character of some, if not most, of the material.

A further provision has been added, modelled on existing section 6P of the Royal Commission Act, to enable the Royal Commissioner to pass on material to law enforcement authorities where that is the appropriate course. The law enforcement authorities named in the Bill are the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth, of a State or of the Northern Territory; the Director of Public Prosecutions; a Special Prosecutor appointed under the Special Prosecutors Act; the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or of the police force of a State or of the Northern Territory; or the authority or person responsible for the administration or enforcement of the law in question; and also the National Crime Authority.

I make one personal comment. This morning's Daily Telegraph contains an editorial which suggests an incorrect background. I would have thought that the position would have been understood by responsible editorials, but the editorial in that newspaper is superficial and ill-informed. It says that the Age tapes was a one-off case. I make the point that that is not so. There is no confusion in anybody's mind as to the distinction that exists between the Age material which was of no value or not thought to be of any value in prosecution-therefore, Mr Temby recommended that indemnities not be granted-and new material or other material which may now be of value, and accordingly indemnities perhaps should be considered. I draw that distinction.

It should also be made clear that there is the question of the High Court's decisions in matters such as Bunning v. Cross, and in the last 48 hours in the Hilton case. Such decisions make it clear also, irrespective of whether indemnities are granted, that the court still has a discretion on the basis of whether it will admit evidence illegally obtained. I make that point because the editor does not seem to understand it. The terms of the Commission which I have just outlined make it clear that the Government is determined to achieve a careful balance between law enforcement and the rights of a private individual to privacy. There is no question that the Government will tolerate any corruption. Equally, there will be no question of any police being led to believe that they can break the law with impunity.

Having said that, I think that what we now have before the House is an opportunity to pursue energetically all matters related to criminal evidence and the prosecution of criminals as well as getting the balance of safeguards of rights of citizens. It will be noticed that an onerous responsibility is placed on Mr Justice Stewart to carry out that function. He is an outstanding judge and we welcome his efforts in the pursuit of crime. I make one final point. The financial implication of the Bill, if the Commission runs its full term, would be approximately $1.5m. I make that as a point of comment. Of course, if the Commission finishes in a shorter period of time, we would expect the outlay to reduce accordingly. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, but it does no credit to the Government that it should be introduced so late and so reluctantly. The Government has had to be pushed and prodded every inch of the way into taking this action, which is at least one step towards fighting and, hopefully, stamping out organised crime in Australia. The Government has resisted every move by the Opposition to grapple with the problem and to make some positive response to it. It is only when the Government has been backed into a corner, when its case is in tatters, when its Attorney-General is discredited, when its whole defence has been shown to be riddled with evasion, contradiction and prevarication, when it has nowhere else to turn, that it has reluctantly and grudgingly agreed to take this action. This Bill is part of a package-a package that is a belated response by the Government to the Opposition's demand to take action on the Age tapes, the new taped material and the matters that emerge from them. Other parts of the package are referred to in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be made perfectly plain at the outset that the sophistry of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that we heard in the latter part of his remarks just will not stand up. The Government has had access to all of this material, and the belated attempt by the Attorney-General to say 'We have changed our position simply because there is new material which has appeared from nowhere and to which we have now given consideration' is a false defence. It is a defence which is full of holes and will not stand up.

I shall elaborate on that further. The first part of this package concerns the need for a new royal commission and the Government's reluctant agreement to establish it. The Opposition demanded a royal commission a year ago, and the Government rejected it. The Government said that there was no need for a royal commission; and it said that only three days ago. As recently as three days ago the Attorney-General was on his feet in this House saying that there was no need for a royal commission into these matters. Three days ago the Government had before it all the material it has today, all the material about which the Attorney-General now has the gall to say: 'Here is new material which should be investigated. We have only just discovered it and here is our instantaneous response'. It is not an instantaneous response. It is a response that has been drawn from the Government like drawing teeth. Three days ago it said that it was opposed to a royal commission and now it says to the public and to the Parliament that there is a need for a royal commission.

What a remarkable turnabout that is. What has brought about this death-bed conversion? Is it because of some new zeal to fight organised crime, some new commitment which has emerged in the last three days to investigate the material that has been revealed? Of course not. The Government made it perfectly plain only three days ago that it would oppose the establishment of a royal commission. Listen to the Attorney-General speaking in this debate on Monday. He said:
I think the Opposition is getting carried away with the suggestion that a royal commission will establish anything different from what Mr Justice Stewart can do.
Who is getting carried away today, if the Government is now proposing a new royal commission? The Opposition was right on Monday to propose a royal commission and it is right to do so today.

That, of course, was only Monday. On Monday there was no need for a royal commission. The Attorney-General's position on Tuesday was that the terms of Mr Justice Stewart's inquiry were 'limited'. He said: 'I think they are not sufficient. I think they have to be widened.' One can see coming up over the horizon some glimmer of appreciation by the Government that, slowly but surely, it was being dragged into taking new and positive action. What could explain such a remarkable change? On Monday the judge's terms were adequate. By Tuesday they were not. What had happened overnight? By Tuesday night there was a need for a virtually new royal commission. By Wednesday morning the Government had gone one step further, believe it or not. By Tuesday night there was a need only for a virtually new royal commission, but by Wednesday it was a fully fledged new royal commission that was needed, launched, and away and flying.

There can be only one reason for these extraordinary changes, for this death-bed conversion by the Government; that is, that the Government has been driven into the position where it has had to concede that its opposition to a royal commission simply cannot be propped up any longer against the weight of public opinion, the Press and this Parliament. To use that memorable phrase we heard the other day in this Parliament, the Attorney-General has been 'caught out'. No one can believe that the Government has any serious commitment to fighting organised crime when it has opposed, and opposed repeatedly, every constructive suggestion put to it by the Opposition and by the Press, including the demand for a royal commission.

What we have said about this death-bed conversion so far as a royal commission is concerned applies equally as far as indemnities are concerned to prove the police tapes, the raw material. What extraordinary changes in the Government's threadbare position we have seen on this issue over the last few days. What was the position last Wednesday? Last Wednesday, the Attorney-General's view was that the police 'are not entitled to indemnity'.

He went further than that. Not only were the police not entitled to indemnity, but they were criminals so far as the Attorney-General was concerned; they had committed crimes and they were deserving of what he called punitive action. It is a black day in the long history of Attorneys-General when we hear one Attorney-General in the Parliament of the Commonwealth saying: 'These people are criminals. Do not wait for the trials. Do not wait for the charges. The police are criminals and they are deserving of punishment'. That was the position on Wednesday. I make it clear that last Wednesday his view was that the police are not-I repeat, not-entitled to indemnity. Until Thursday on the AM radio program he was-I give him this-at least consistent. On Thursday he said: 'I cannot give them an indemnity'. By Thursday night, not surprisingly, there had been another change; his office, presumably with his authority, was saying that those views were the Attorney-General's personal view; that no formal decision, one way or the other, had yet been made.

By Thursday's Question Time, needless to say, there was another variation, another grudging step forward. The line on indemnities was: 'The matter has not been finalised'. I repeat that the Attorney-General had all the facts, all the taped material-whatever form the material may be in-while these sea changes were under way. By Tuesday of this week, the Attorney-General was off again. By this time the Director of Public Prosecutions, who had been the great prop of the argument the week before, had been abandoned. He had been left behind as being of no use at all to the Government's case. According to the Attorney-General on Tuesday: 'If Mr Justice Stewart recommended an indemnity I see no reason why I should not give it'.

Can anyone believe that this Government is committed to the fight against organised crime? Can anyone believe that the Government has its heart in these proposals? Can anyone believe that the Government has a firm commitment on these matters when, with all the material before it during the whole period of this pathetic, tragi-comedy, the Government makes so many changes in its position. What a remarkable somersault! Last week, the police were branded as criminals deserving of punishment and certainly not entitled to indemnities. Then came what I could call the final capitulation-the amendment in the Bill before us today to allow the taped material to be used before the new royal commission, which the Government was opposing root and branch only days ago.

. . . a document or information arising out of or relating to the unlawful interception--
of telecommunications-
(whether before or after the commencement of this section).

I read that to mean that the unlawful interception may take place after this section comes into operation. From what the Attorney-General put earlier, I understood him to say: 'There are some limits on this. Nothing that happens after today will have any effect at all'. —Yes, yes, but why does the honourable member not listen for a change. I will tell him something else about the Costigan Royal Commission report. It was this Government that set it up.
