SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, let it not be overlooked that the former Government established the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. The Government is trading on Mr Justice Stewart's good name and achievements in the very action it is taking today. Do not forget who initiated that inquiry. It was initiated in the time of the previous Government. I remind honourable members, thirdly, that it was the previous Government that introduced the Special Prosecutors Bill 1982 and appointed Mr Gyles and Mr Redlich, who have been just as responsible as Mr Justice Stewart in the achievements made so far in this country in the fight against organised crime. So do not point a finger at us and say that we were lax in taking steps to combat organised crime. We did far more in our term of government than the present Government has done, and we did it far more honestly.

Let me elaborate a little on that point of honesty. One of the things the Attorney-General says is: 'Look at the powers we are giving the Director of Public Prosecutions. We are giving him power to take civil proceedings'. If we look at the record during the election period we will find that the Opposition put that as part of its policy to the people. When I introduced a private member's Bill to give the Director of Public Prosecutions power to conduct civil proceedings and recover moneys due to the Commonwealth and to the people, the Government within hours announced it was going to do the same thing. It would not have moved an inch if the Opposition had not threatened it with taking parliamentary action. The Government's record is slack, and it continues to be slack. The slackest performance of all is the disgraceful charade we have seen over this whole matter in the last two weeks. The Government's record is weak and dishonest.

Let me point to the dishonesty. The Attorney-General is parading a Press release and saying: 'Look what we have done with our task force on extradition treaties. Aren't we good? We have actually got an extradition treaty with Finland'. What a remarkable achievement. We have an extradition treaty with Finland. I know the Attorney-General is reluctant to read anything-he will not read the transcript of the Age tapes and he will not read any of the raw material; if he did he would not be making the stupid statement of the sort he is making today-but if he reads the Stewart Royal Commission report he will see that Mr Justice Stewart told the Government two years ago that an extradition treaty was being negotiated with Finland. It is there in black and white. To come out and say, as the Attorney-General said two days ago, that the task force, which had been established in February of this year, had produced its first remarkable achievement, an extradition treaty with Finland, is an absolute distortion of the truth because the Government was told by Mr Justice Stewart, at the beginning of 1983, that this extradition treaty was being negotiated. The Government has the gall to adopt this dishonest-and I use the word advisedly-position that the extradition treaty with Finland was the result of its great task force on extradition treaties. What an absolute distortion of the facts. If the Government is parading its record on organised crime it should look at its performance with Mr Trimbole. I do not know whether any of the people to whom we are giving taxation assistance to make films are making a film about that, but they should, and they should call it the Keystone Cops. The Government's handling of that matter, from beginning to end, was an absolute shambles.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened under your Government?

—I suppose the Attorney General is entitled to interject because his position is pretty hopeless. He says now: 'Your record on extradition treaties with Ireland was pretty hopeless'. I would have to concede that the Whitlam Government's performance was appalling. The Attorney-General can tell Mr Whitlam that when he sees him next, if Mr Whitlam is still talking to him. No government in Australia has taken a proper and responsible attitude to extradition treaties. It is a fair defence for both the Whitlam and Fraser governments that neither government took adequate action on extradition treaties until the problems of organised crime became so apparent and until organised criminals started to use their current method of bribery to obtain passports and forgery of passports.

SPEECH.PARA: What has the Government done since it was told by the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking that it should be monitoring its extradition treaties, keeping them in working order and making sure that they were effective? The Government has done absolutely nothing about that. The Government says that it has established the National Crime Authority-this powerful body which will get to the bottom of organised crime. We will keep the pressure on the Government and we will be asking how many prosecutions have been brought as a result of the activities of this Authority. We will be expecting some answers. We say that the Authority does not have enough powers. The Government is deficient in exercising its responsibility in not giving the Authority the powers that it needs. We will continue to ask about the results of the National Crime Authority's work and we will expect some answers.

In addition to those matters we say to the Government that it should not think that simply by putting the word 'indemnities' into the concocted speech of today it will bring the indemnities issue to an end. I think that the indemnities, as the Government has them set out in the statement, are probably not as adequate as they should be. I do not know what sort of indemnity the Government proposes. I do not know whether the Government proposes the functional indemnity, as it is called, or the more all-embracing indemnity. But it will have to set to work because it has plenty of work ahead of it in working out exactly what sorts of indemnities should be granted. It is not apparent from what the Attorney-General has put to the House today exactly what sorts of indemnities will be granted. He has an obligation to make that apparent. We say in addition to that that there should be a full statement on the terms of reference of the Royal Commission so that everyone knows exactly where they stand and what the Government is proposing about those precise terms.

I simply say to the Attorney-General that there should be a detailed statement of what the powers of the Royal Commission and its terms of reference will be. We will want a full statement to satisfy us that Mr Justice Stewart has the time and the resources to carry out his activities. Finally, we will be following what happens in this matter. It is no credit to the Government that at this late stage it should be taking these measures. It is no credit to the Government that it should be taking those measures only as the result of prodding and pushing. Its case has been utterly defenceless right from the beginning. Now, at least, it has been forced, grudgingly and reluctantly at the last gasp, into taking some action. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House calls upon the Government:

(1) to ensure that Mr Justice Stewart is provided with personnel and material resources, including the services of senior counsel and other assistants sufficient for this inquiry to be completed with thoroughness, effectiveness and expedition, and

(2) to be satisfied that Mr Justice Stewart's other important inquiries into the Nugan Hand Bank and the ''Mr Asia'' Affair and his work as the Chairman of the National Crime Authority are able to proceed without hindrance or disruption in addition to the further inquiries which are the subject of this Bill'.

Nobody disagrees with that statement. Honourable members opposite seem very conveniently to have forgotten it when they come in here today and lay at the feet of the Attorney-General totally unfounded allegations to the effect that he has delayed far too long in this matter. At some stage during this debate let us hope that two questions will be answered. The shadow Attorney-General in his speech then moved into another area in which honourable members opposite still seem to me to get some comfort. It becomes more amazing as the matter goes on as to how honourable members opposite get comfort out of it. The shadow Attorney-General referred to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Costigan Royal Commission was set up by the Fraser Government to embark on an attack on the trade union movement through the Ship Painters and Dockers Union. What happened in relation to that really set honourable members opposite back on their heels and put them where they are now. What came out of the Costigan Royal Commission was a saga of the most appalling lack of action by the Fraser Government from 1975 on in relation to the most horrendous tax evasion that had taken place in this country throughout that period. The explosion of tax evasion and tax avoidance during the period of the Fraser Government is something which the Opposition will wear to its eternal disgrace for as long as the Liberal Party of Australia exists. The fact is that the then Government had no idea where the Costigan Commission was leading it. If that Government had known, there is no way that the Costigan Commission would have been set up.

Let us now look at the question of organised crime generally. It is an issue which honourable members opposite love to talk about in their self-righteous manner. Honourable members opposite really do talk about the world as if they were the only people concerned about crime, education and moral matters in the community. They trot out the most nauseating and sickening stuff over and over again. The most unfortunate part is that I am starting to think honourable members opposite do not use it just for political reasons but now have reached the ultimate stage of self-delusion and are starting to believe it. That is the sort of nonsense we have to put up with.

Let us look at the organised crime position so I can put the record straight. We can be proud of this Government's record in relation to organised crime when it is compared to the pathetic performance honourable members opposite put up during their period of Government, particularly the period 1975 to 1983. Let us look at what has happened under this Government. It was the Hawke Government, not the Fraser Government, which established an independent Director of Public Prosecutions. A year ago, in March 1984, Mr Temby had four lawyers and a few support staff. That was the position. Twelve months later, in March 1985, he has 100 lawyers and many support staff. That is how seriously this Government took the question of crime when it established the post of Director of Public Prosecutions.

Within the near future Mr Temby will be in the position of having 150 lawyers and about the same number of support staff. Are honourable members opposite seriously suggesting that a government which acts in this way is not serious about organised crime? Honourable members opposite cannot possibly be serious if they are putting such a stupid proposal. That in fact is what they are on about. That is what was said. The point is that it is not the number of staff the Director of Public Prosecutions has but what they are doing. The fact is that this Government has given the Director of Public Prosecutions-the mob opposite could not have done that because it did not have a director-sufficient resources to enable him to engage in literally thousands of prosecutions.

That is a situation that will involve enormously complex cases in many areas. Let us think about some of those areas. One of the most significant areas the Director of Public Prosecutions will be involved in will concern bottom of the harbour prosecutions, an area in which prosecutions have never been launched in this country before. Honourable members opposite had legal opinions which clearly showed that there could have been prosecutions for conspiracy in relation to those matters. What did the then Government do? It did nothing. It allowed that massive tax evasion. Of course, at the same time tax evasion money has to be used somewhere. This was moved into the major narcotic offences and all the other areas we are now talking about. The honourable member for Menzies who today berated the present Attorney-General was the Acting Attorney-General for a large part of the Fraser Government's period in office.

I now move to the National Crime Authority. It was this Government, not the Opposition when in government, that established an effective crime authority acting in full co-operation with the States. The Crime Authority would not have worked if it had not been for that co-operation. Honourable members opposite all know that. There is no doubt about that. It was not an easy task for the Government to bring that co-operation about. Again that relates to what we heard today. The shadow Attorney-General came in here and asked: 'Why didn't you do this yesterday; why didn't you do this three weeks ago; why didn't you do that a month ago?' The reason is that the Government acts in a considered way on these matters. The same applied with the National Crime Authority. The Opposition would have gone on with it and not cared what the States said about it. The Opposition would have got it into a worse mess than it was already in because it would not have worked. The establishment of the National Crime Authority was not an easy task, as I said, but it is now established and with the full co-operation of the States it will make a major contribution to fighting organised crime in this country.

I move now to the Australian Federal Police. That was a nice performance from the shadow Attorney-General. I go back to 1981 when the Joint Committee of Public Accounts investigated matters involving medifraud. One of the areas looked at concerned the total lack of resources provided to the Australian Federal Police to investigate medifraud. The fact was that the Joint Committee said that the Federal Police did not have anywhere near sufficient resources to fight medifraud or, for that matter, any type of organised crime. The evidence given by the then Acting Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police before that Committee supported that view. I suggest that honourable members opposite start to think about some of those things before they come in here and abuse the present Attorney-General.
I refer now to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. The Opposition sat in government from 1975 until it was chucked out in 1983 and did bloody nothing. That is what happened.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has also moved to increase the power of the Director of Public Prosecutions-honourable members opposite could not have done that because they did not have one-to use civil remedies to move against the assets of organised criminals in a way, providing greater deterrence than was the case before he was able to do that. That seems to be something members of the Opposition conveniently overlook when they criticise the Government for not acting as quickly as they say they it ought to act; that is, yesterday or the week before or something else. In that area it is necessary, as it was with the National Crime Authority, to have the co-operation of the States. This Government, in co-operation with the States, has moved to ensure the forfeiture of assets of organised criminals, people who prey on this society and destroy the lives of our young people.

Why did honourable members opposite not do something about it? When will someone answer those sorts of allegations in this House? Let members of the Opposition go through the record of what they did between 1975 and 1983 and when they were finally turfed out. They did nothing, as I said earlier. It is absolutely sickening to have to listen to the moral self-righteousness that they go on with every time this sort of debate crops up, as if they are paragons of virtue and the only people who know anything about law enforcement. Again, the previous Government did nothing in the narcotics area. That is one of the reasons that this Government has such an enormous problem on its hands today, a problem which it will deal with. We will deal with that problem. We will deal with it through the National Crime Authority in particular. We will deal with it by giving the Australian Federal Police the resources that the miserable lot opposite starved them of right through their term of government. From 1975 to 1983 the Australian Federal Police were starved of resources, to the stage that the then Acting Commissioner said before a joint committee of this House that the Federal Police did not have sufficient resources to fight medifraud or, for that matter, any organised crime. As I said, as to the Australian Bureau of Criminology, we have moved to take civil remedies to allow the Director of Public Prosecutions to move against the assets of organised criminals. That is something that would never have crossed the minds of honourable members opposite. Apart from anything else, they had no will to do it and, even if they had had the will, they would not have had sufficient intelligence. That was their problem. They have stumbled on and the only thing they can do here is abuse the Attorney-General and go on to talk about the Costigan Royal Commission.

I end where I started. The Costigan Royal Commission blew up in the face of those opposite. That is what happened. The Costigan Royal Commission was set up in an attempt to slur the trade union movement, starting with the painters and dockers, and it all went wrong. It all went wrong for the Fraser Government because the Commissioner decided that there was so much rottenness in this society on the evidence put before him that he was not prepared to protect in any way the sort of people who were involved in tax evasion and those highly contrived methods of tax avoidance that had gone on, on which those opposite, when in government, had an opinion. TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the House is a comparatively simple one. I begin by saying that I believe that the people of Australia, and I think all honourable members in this House, could accept as a general proposition that honourable members on all sides of the House are committed to effective government action to deal with the problems of organised crime. In respect of that, I do not claim that all knowledge or all wisdom necessarily lies on the Government side of the House. A positive contribution could be made by members of the Opposition. The question before the House is a comparatively simple one. It is whether this amendment adds to the armoury of the Government in its task in combating the effects of organised crime. In respect of that, the Opposition has answered simply yes. It supports the amendment. If, indeed, in supporting the amendment it had made perhaps some positive criticism and suggested some positive actions, the matter could have been quickly disposed of.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it a matter of regret for the Parliament and a matter of concern to the general public that, in supporting the legislation, we heard from the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) an ill-thought-through, provocative and, in some areas, untruthful attack upon the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). It is to deal with those problems very quickly that I simply want to draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that this Attorney-General was, on the question of indemnities, confronted with a difficult problem. It was not a problem which could be dealt with simply or easily. Mr Justice Stewart had the problem, in trying to complete his inquiry as quickly as possible, of seeking the co-operation of members of the police force in New South Wales who had taped phone conversations in breach of Commonwealth legislation. One can understand and respect the position of Mr Justice Stewart in his desire to get to the bottom of that and his view that, in doing that, he would be assisted by the granting of indemnities.

The problem that confronted the Attorney-General was that he had very strong advice from Mr Temby, who also has a responsibility in this matter, first of all, doubting the weight of the evidence and the usefulness of the evidence which would come from the granting of such indemnities and, secondly, advising the Attorney-General against granting such indemnities. That constituted a problem of some political dimension which quite properly the Attorney-General, I think, in the final analysis had to resolve. The Attorney-General has resolved that matter in the legislation that is now before the House. It has been suggested that, in resolving this issue, he has acted slowly, carelessly and not in the best interests of the nation. All those allegations do not stand any proper examination. I refer to the statements in the House today by the honourable member for Menzies when he described the Attorney-General as having been pushed and prodded and the Government as being backed into a corner and the contradictory positions which he alleged had been taken.

Let us look at some of those positions. Let us look at the position of the honourable member for Menzies who was, after all, the spokesman for the Opposition on these matters. On 20 March 1985 the contribution of the honourable member for Menzies to the resolution of this difficult and complex issue before the Attorney-General was to refer to the conflicting advice given to the Attorney-General by Mr Temby and by Mr Justice Stewart. I am using his own terms; he referred to the conflicting advice. So the nature and the quality of the advice and the issues involved were fully known and understood by the honourable member for Menzies. He then went on to suggest-his first positive suggestion-that, by virtue of an interview which he described, albeit as an innocent one, there could be the appearance of a conflict of interest and so the Attorney-General should completely divorce himself from any of these decisions. This is the man who, a matter of days later, is saying in this Parliament that the Attorney-General has not acted as quickly as he should.

One is entitled to the view that political points from time to time will be taken. But has there ever been a less efficacious argument, a more unworthy argument, than that of the shadow Attorney-General, understanding the nature of the issue that has to be resolved by the Attorney-General, when in this Parliament today, in carping about the need for urgent action in order to advance what he would see as some kind of political advantage to the Opposition less than a matter of days ago, he said: 'Look, we understand the nature of the problem. We also understand that the Attorney-General had a completely innocent interview when he was a member of the Opposition. But we think the struggle against organised crime can be advanced if the Attorney-General stands back and divorces himself from all of this- from the knowledge, from the detailed work that has to be done.'? What kind of positive contribution is that? Let us get to the question of credibility in respect of this matter. On the very same day in this House in answer to that question, in answer to the issues that had to be resolved, on the question of the indemnities of members of the police force, the Attorney-General said:
Mr Temby QC advises me that they-
that is, the police-
are not entitled to an indemnity, and he is the Director of Public Prosecutions.

I ask the House to weigh those words carefully because here is a statement made by the Attorney-General in answer to a question proffered by the shadow Attorney-General in which the Attorney-General quite clearly set out the nature of the problem. I repeat that he said:
Mr Temby QC advises me that they-
the police-
are not entitled to an indemnity, and he is the Director of Public Prosecutions.

That seems to me to be a fair, accurate and appropriate statement but in the hands of the honourable member for Menzies and this desperate Opposition, an Opposition which would like to suggest to the people of Australia that organised crime is actually an invention of the Hawke Labor Government, how did that answer become transformed and distorted? The honourable member for Menzies, in a matter of public importance raised in the House by him, transformed that statement, an accurate statement of what Mr Temby had advised the Attorney-General, into a statement in which, in the words of the honourable member for Menzies, the Attorney-General has said that the police are criminals. I have looked at the Hansard very carefully and I have looked at the reports very carefully. Nowhere in an answer given by the Attorney-General to the shadow Attorney-General have those terms been used. In a glib interpretation of the answer given by the Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies has taken those words, interpreted them in a way which would give him maximum political advantage and put them into the Attorney-General's mouth. He has then come in here saying what a dreadful thing it is for an Attorney-General to make the unprecedented statement that the police who took these tapes were criminals.

I have had the benefit of reading the advice that Mr Temby proffered to the Attorney-General. He had some very harsh comments to make about the activities of these police, about both their reluctance to co-operate with Mr Justice Stewart and their seeking, not merely from the Commonwealth but also from the State of New South Wales, an indemnity for actions which they must have known were illegal. These are important issues. They go not merely to the question of fighting organised crime but to the rights and the liberties of the Australian citizen. In dealing with these matters the people of Australia are entitled to the view that, if the Attorney-General has been diligent in his responses that ought to be a matter of proper and effective criticism by the Opposition. But they are not entitled to expect what they have received today-a deliberate and wilful distortion of the statements made to this House by the Attorney-General for the purposes of seeking a narrow political advantage.

The fact is that the Attorney-General has responded, I believe appropriately and with great propriety, to a set of alternative views from Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby, both of whom have great responsibility in this area. In respect of the latest piece of advice he has received he has immediately come into this Parliament today with legislation to deal with this issue. He said: 'No, the Opposition cannot criticise it'. But we got an intemperate, carping, ill-informed and dishonest statement. The damage that that does-not to the credibility of the honourable member for Menzies; frankly, that is his problem-is to suggest to the people of Australia that the Attorney-General has acted with a lack of speed and a lack of propriety in this matter, which is completely untrue. The suggestion that has been made by the honourable member for Menzies does him no credit and, when it is put forward on behalf of the Opposition, it does the Opposition no credit. Of course, the Opposition wants to make a political point, and any political point will do for this Opposition, irrespective of whose reputation it damages or which particular position it produces.

The two parts of the second reading amendment will not be accepted by the Government. The first part is designed to ensure that Mr Justice Stewart is provided with personnel and material resources. In Cabinet this morning the decision was made to grant Mr Justice Stewart an additional million and a half dollars to deal with these matters. The action has already been taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is reasonable, isn't it?
—I think it is reasonable. The honourable member might want to add another million or two, but I would have thought that that is not unreasonable.
—The amendment is reasonable, surely.

—I put it this way: I am telling the honourable member that the Government has already taken action. If the Government is taking action, I do not know why he wants to delay the House. He is the one who is saying that we have to act urgently in this matter. The second part states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to be satisfied that Mr Justice Stewart's other important inquiries is into the Nugan Hand Bank and the 'Mr Asia' Affair and his work as the Chairman of the National Crime Authority are able to proceed without hindrance or disruption in addition to the further inquiries which are the subject of this Bill.

The implication of that is, of course, that there may be or could be some hindrance to Mr Justice Stewart's inquiries. Of course, the fact is that Mr Justice Stewart, as Chairman of the National Crime Authority, will be in a position, as a result of the work that is being done by him in this other area, to immediately transfer any knowledge that he gains there to his other position. He has been made fully aware of the position. The positions that have emerged in this Bill, as is known to the Opposition, came about after full consultation with Mr Justice Stewart and indeed with Mr Temby. Despite that, we have an amendment which is concerned to make ridiculous points-I do not know whether the honourable member for Menzies knew of the Cabinet decision to provide an additional million and a half dollars or whether he applied his mind to that-which are evidence of the fact that the whole approach of the Opposition, faced with a piece of legislation designed to move this thing forward expeditiously, is to come up with another plodding and irrelevant amendment in the hope that someone out there, someone in the broader community, might feel that the Government is not responding in a positive way to the problems of dealing with organised crime. For those reasons, the amendment will not be accepted.

I believe I have dealt with the lack of credibility in the thoroughly false statements which have been made about the actions of the Attorney-General in this matter. Having looked at the record, I for one would compliment the Attorney-General on dealing with this matter in a thoroughly principled way by bringing into the House legislation designed to meet the problems. I condemn the carping and irresponsible statements that have been made here. The Opposition has a duty in this House to come forward with positive criticisms in terms of the problems of organised crime that confront this community. To date, any objective analysis of its position on this matter could only lead to the conclusion that it is more concerned to score any kind of political point, no matter how low, no matter how irresponsible, than to try to assist this Government with its responsibility in meeting the problems that all of us have to face in dealing with organised crime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today we have heard from the Government three speeches of grinding irrelevance as it seeks to make a virtue of surrender, surrender to the Opposition, surrender to public opinion. We all know-it has been said before in this House-the scorn, derision and contempt, that has been poured on the Opposition over the months because of the way in which the Opposition has pursued the Age tape material. Finally we get a decision from the Government which is a chapter in a history of gross incompetence and that decision is to do precisely what the Opposition has been urging it to do. Why is it that there has been this change of opinion? Is it not crucial to ask'. How is it that the Government came to change its view about indemnities, and about a royal commission? The Government would have us believe that it was a matter of mature, careful, slow, reflection. Well, God knows, it was slow; mature it certainly was not, careful it most certainly was not. But a hint of the real reason is to be found in an answer which was given by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) on 25 March, when the Leader of the Opposition asked this question:

SPEECH.PARA: When did the Attorney-General first learn that the interceptions had continued from 1981 to 1984? How many interceptions was he advised took place in that period? What action has he taken to ascertain the identity of those involved, the instructions given to set up the interceptions, and the use made of those interceptions?
It will be recalled that we had only just learnt that the interceptions had continued up until 1984. The answer which the Attorney-General gave, on the point, was this:
. . . it would have been in December.

It was in December of 1984 and yet it was not until well after mid-March 1985 that the Australian people got any hint of the continuance of these interceptions. It was perfectly open to the Attorney-General to make a statement detailing the fact that interceptions had taken place through to 1984, the nature of those interceptions and the action that the Government was going to take, but he did not. It had to come out after a series of questions. What was the reason for this manifestation of apparent frankness? It is a curious thing that on the previous weekend there was an interview with a policeman who made allegations about the interceptions continuing up until now. It is also a very curious thing that a letter was written by a concerned policeman, apparently a copy of that letter has been sent to Mr Greiner. That concerned policeman blew the whistle on the New South Wales Government and at the same time planted a bomb which went up underneath the Attorney-General. It then became apparent to everybody in the know-the Attorney-General may have an answer to this and I will be very glad to hear it if there is one-that it could no longer be kept quiet, that the interceptions had continued up and through 1984. Why were we not advised immediately he knew of it? Can any answer be given to that? It was surely in the public interest that this House be told and that the Australian people be told.

Let me move to the amendment. The reason for the amendment has been outlined here and the honourable member for Menzies has spoken on it. The purpose, in short, is to authorise Mr Justice Stewart to use intercepted information for the purposes of his inquiry, that is, the inquiry which he is to conduct. It is to authorise those in possession of illegally obtained information to communicate that information to Stewart J. and to do it in a manner which will not subject those persons to an offence. One might say: So far, so good. It is then to authorise Mr Justice Stewart to communicate intercepted material to the law enforcement agencies-they have been named-if the material relates to an offence or a possible offence.

Honourable members will recall the Attorney-General saying in the House, amongst other things that, if an offence was disclosed, that was to be reported by Mr Justice Stewart, who was also to report, I understand, to the Attorney-General-I invite him to correct me now if I misheard him-on the admissibility of evidence. Clearly, what the Government has in mind, and I support it, is that Mr Justice Stewart is to obtain, so far as he can, admissible evidence from the intercept material which can be used to prove criminal charges. We would all support that.

What is going to be the position? Will that be the case? Has this Government thought about the very recent decision of the High Court, which was handed down in the case of Hilton v. Christopher and others? The Attorney-General referred to it in passing. That was a decision of a five-bench High Court. The bench split 3:2. The minority, made up of Mr Justice Mason and Mr Justice Deane, expressed the view that evidence which had been obtained illegally-that is, intercepts-could not be admitted into evidence because to do so was contrary to the Telecommunications (Interception Act) 1979.

If that decision were to be changed by a further application to the High Court and the two justices-Mr Justice Murphy and Mr Justice Brennan-sat, the result would be that none of the material which is to be referred to Mr Justice Stewart, and which he is obliged to refer to law enforcement agencies in the circumstances clearly set out in the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, could be used. Proposed new section 7BA (4) states:

Where, in the course of holding an inquiry referred to in sub-section (2), the Honourable Donald Gerard Stewart obtains a document or information that relates, or that may relate, to the commission of an offence, or evidence of the commission of an offence, against a law of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory, he may, if in his opinion it is appropriate to do so, give the document or . . . information . . . to-

any one of a number of the listed law enforcement agencies. The purpose of the exercise is to prosecute criminals. Lest it be thought that a re-hearing of the very recent issue which has gone before the High Court is unlikely, I refer to today's Australian where we see, in a report on page 3, that an application has been made to quash the warrants which were originally made in the Hilton case and on which the evidence against Mr Hilton and others apparently rests. Does anyone really think that someone faced with a case which depends upon intercepted evidence will not take that case to the High Court? An example is conspiracy to commit murder. What would be the consequence of the High Court, with the two additional justices sitting, coming to the conclusion that the minority view was right? That would frustrate everything that we are seeking here to do. I therefore propose that the Government should accept an amendment along the following lines. I am sorry I have not had time to type it out, but we have had rather short notice of this debate and it is something which occurred to me as I was examining the Bill. I suggest that, at the end of proposed new section 7BA, the following be inserted:

Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, that subject otherwise to the rules as to admissibility of evidence, documents or information falling within section 7BA(1) or oral evidence of intercepts may be admitted in evidence in criminal proceedings.

Unless we do something like that we may be engaged in a perfectly fruitless exercise, and that would be simply another chapter in incompetence. The Government must now be on clear and plain notice of that. I ask the Attorney-General to give some thought to that and ask his advisers to do so also.

I now move on to one or two other matters. The next point that I wish to make relates to the terms of section 7BA(1). I understand that we are going into Committee so I will not take up time on this. I simply raise the question now so that the Attorney-General will understand what the question is. The power to disclose without being subject to a penalty is confined to what is called 'unlawfully obtained material'. That material is further defined as meaning:
. . . a document or information . . . that discloses the commission of an offence or the possible commission of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or a law of a Territory.

In passing, I ask why do we not have the words 'a law of a State' in there as well, since we are, after all, concerned with that when we come to section 7BA(4). Putting that blunder to one side, the question that needs to be asked is: How is a person in possession of material that Mr Justice Stewart should see going to make for himself the decision as to whether or not that material discloses the commission or possible commission of an offence? What is he likely to do? If there is any doubt he will not hand it over because, if he hands over material that does not disclose an offence or the possible commission of an offence, he has no indemnity. Therefore, it is plain that the definition needs to be enlarged. That, I think, is the third blunder which has been demonstrated in this Bill, brought forward today by the Attorney-General, proudly announcing that he has solved it all.

There are one or two other matters that I would like to touch upon before I sit down. First of all, I would like to say something about what has been said by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). He has raised some questions which his Government should be answering. First of all, he talked about the 'no further action required' file, which he said was dated 4 January 1982. We have heard the Attorney-General tell this House: 'There was a lost treaty, the lost treaty turned up in a drawer somewhere and, dear me, these things happen, but it happened during your time'. Perhaps the Attorney-General could tell us whether the treaty had been signed. It had not, I would assume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! It was initialled.

—It was initialled. Was it initialled between the governments? Can he tell us what was done by him when the Trimbole question arose to see what the state of extradition was between Ireland and Australia? Will he tell why, in the time between learning that Trimbole was in Ireland and making the application to the Irish court, an extradition treaty was not concluded between the two countries in the briefest possible time, particularly as there was a copy lying around in the drawer? It would have been a matter of great ease, one would think. The Attorney would have asked his Department: What do we know about Ireland? What treaties do we have with Ireland? Somebody would have said: 'Look, we have something sitting in the drawer; we had better dig it out'. That is the first question that he would have asked. That question was obviously not asked by him.
—Oh, come on; wake up!
—Well, let the Attorney tell us what the fact is.
—Is the matter relevant to the Bill before the House?

—Yes, Madam Deputy Speaker, it is, because it has been raised by the Minister who spoke on the subject. We know in this House that anything the Minister says must be relevant. That, at least, is the ruling which we in opposition have experience of getting. The Stewart recommendations told the Government to monitor the treaties. Why has that not been done? Why was it not done in Trimbole's case? How is it that this Attorney-General can come here talking about a lost treaty without telling us what was involved, whether it was a treaty, when it was signed and who knew about it? How is it that he can say: 'Look, when I came to Trimbole, as with any other matter, I acted with the kind of diligence that you would expect of me'. We know the kind of diligence that we expect of this Attorney-General as he bumbles along, changing and surrendering in his confused and, I am sorry to say, disturbed manner.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we have today? We have a major defeat by this Government. It is not a question of something novel coming up. We have the Attorney accepting what the Opposition has asked for from the very start, under the guise of saying to the Opposition: 'You are wrong and we were right. All I have been doing is getting things in order'. We find that we have before us a Bill which is so framed as to frustrate the intent that this Government apparently seeks to achieve.

Let me go over the three points again. First of all, it is intended that the material that Mr Justice Stewart is going to see should be available for the law enforcement authorities to prosecute criminals. We know that the High Court may rule, and certainly it is likely that it will be called upon to rule, that this material is wholly inadmissible. Yet nothing has been done about that by this Government. We know, as the shadow Attorney-General has pointed out, that the Attorney-General says one thing in his second reading speech-that is, that the interceptions are to stop-and yet plainly in the Bill itself, which he has brought before the House, it is contemplated that the material which is to go to Mr Justice Stewart and which may be covered by the indemnity will include material that becomes available in the future because of future intercepts. We have the situation that those who may wish to disclose material will have to make a judgment as to whether or not that material would support a criminal conviction or may possibly lead to one, and unless it does the material will not be covered by an indemnity.

These are the sorts of questions this Government must look at. If it is truly concerned about dealing with the whole question of the Age tapes and the other material, if it is deeply concerned with making sure that prosecutions take place as a result of Mr Justice Stewart's enlarged terms of reference, the only sensible thing it can do is to plug the holes which apparently exist in the Bill now before the House. I would agree with one thing that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) said. I hope that all of us in this House are concerned to do as much as we can about organised crime. But if the Attorney-General and those with him are concerned to do as much as they can about organised crime, they will agree to some amendments which can be put through very quickly, which will enlarge the net and overcome the kind of technical problems which otherwise might entirely frustrate the intent of Mr Justice Stewart's work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to advert to what the member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) said in a rather ponderous speech. We all know of the recent decision of the High Court in the Hilton case, but the honourable gentleman concentrated more on the minority decision than the majority decision. The majority decision made very clear that the Court would use its discretion as to what evidence could be admitted. I do not know why we waste so much time arguing about the fact that in the future two other judges might be appointed who would reverse the decision. Bunning v. Cross said very much the same thing. It is not really new matter. Admissibility of evidence is subject to discretion.

SPEECH.PARA: We are looking at the question of illegality and to what extent it can be overlooked with the granting of an indemnity. The honourable member for North Sydney also wanted to know how it is that somebody would be able to submit evidence not knowing whether he was going to get indemnity or not. It is a good point, but the Commissioner makes the point that he will invite anybody to submit what information he has without any identification of himself, so there is no problem in that regard. If the information can lead to a prosecution of course an indemnity will be recommended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without identifying themselves?

—Yes, in the initial stage. In other words, we have to get to that position as to who is entitled to indemnity not knowing at that stage whether he has evidence that will lead to a prosecution. That is a matter of procedure which I can tell the honourable member the Commissioner feels will satisfy the position. Let me come to the other point, the issue of why something was not done before. The letters patent now existing relate to the Terrence Clark case and were given in 1981, I might add. For the benefit of the honourable member, Trimbole left this country in 1981 and nobody did anything about that. I make the point that there were letters patent at that time that related to those sorts of matters but the government of the time did not see fit to prevent people leaving the country. The honourable member ought to address his mind to that. The real issue is why the terms of reference are now to be expanded. The terms of reference I feel have to be expanded. I notice all Opposition members agree. It is obvious that there might have been illegal interception right up to the present. There is no evidence of it, but that might have been the case, so we are not running away from the issue of all of a sudden having to expand the terms of reference.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference relate to the authenticity of material which both Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby say would not be admissible in any prosecution. That is the issue. So on the issue of admissibility, of the worth of the material, Mr Temby properly gave advice that we could not give an indemnity on that because it would not lead to anything. That is perfectly consistent with the principles established over a long period, and established in this House by a statement made in 1982. One just does not give indemnity when there is no likelihood of a prosecution. Both Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby have that view. I have had to take the view, as there may be other material not yet available, that we should explore the issue of indemnity there. Both Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby agree that if there is evidence, and there is none at the moment, if there is anybody with evidence that can come forward with evidence that would lead to a prosecution or given information that might lead to a prosecution, an indemnity will be considered. Do not let us waste too much more time on that issue. There is a clear distinction. The question of interceptions after this date raises a good point. Cabinet today was aware of that and was concerned about it. I was instructed to tell the Parliament that we would not be approving interceptions after this date. How will we control it? We will control it in the letters patent, and that is the position.

The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) raised matters by way of an amendment whilst not opposing the Bill. He is worried about whether Mr Justice Stewart is satisfied. That is the second part of his amendment. I can assure him Mr Stewart has told me that he is satisfied. The reason is that he has completed most of his inquiries. There is another very interesting point. He feels that if he can get some further evidence it will enable him to finalise one of the inquiries in a matter that I cannot give the actual details of. So it is very helpful to Mr Justice Stewart and he has no difficulties with the matter. In fact it will certainly help every aspect of the matters referred to in the second part of the amendment. In relation to the first part of the amendment, there is no doubt that adequate resources will be made available as and when they are required. At present we are entering into this inquiry not knowing what might be the nature of the evidence that has to be tested.

I do not want to delay the House. There is not a lot of time. I thank members for their contributions. I think my ministerial colleagues have adequately answered the questions of the Opposition not understanding the significance of what is the difference between the two letters patent; the Opposition not understanding the worthlessness of the Age material; the Opposition not understanding the position it announced when in government that we do not give an indemnity where there is no likelihood of a prosecution. I think today's statement clearly indicates the Government is very anxious to proceed with finding out whether there is any evidence at all. If there are chances of prosecutions, indemnity will be granted.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the very short time that we have had, I have not had the opportunity since I have been sitting here whilst the debate has been going on to draw up an amendment of the kind that I had in mind, except very recently. I did explain that to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). I put it to him quite sincerely that it is all very well for him to talk about Bunning v. Wong and to say that the recent decision of the High Court just deals with the same point.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to look at two questions. The High Court has decided-in Bunning v. Wong, and at other times as well-that the question as to whether illegally obtained evidence is allowed to go into evidence depends on a judgment between the public interest in securing a conviction and the public interest in not supporting the illegal obtaining of evidence. That, of course, is one issue. But what the High Court had decided in the very recent case of Hilton v. Christopher has nothing to do with that issue. The decision in the High Court in Hilton's case, by a majority, was that section 7 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act does not prohibit the admission into evidence of information obtained by an illegal interception. That is the majority decision. The Chief Justice, Mr Justice Wilson and Mr Justice Dawson were of that view. That means, of course, that when any question arises, so long as that decision stands as to the admission into evidence of illegally obtained interceptions, that can be done subject always to Bunning v. Wong, which the Attorney-General has referred to, when the court would be able to decide whether or not it should allow the illegally obtained evidence go into evidence.

The point which I have put to the Attorney-General and to the House, and which I wish to put again-with any luck at all my amendment will have been typed by the time I have finished putting the argument-is this: We are dealing with a mass of material. It seems likely from all that we have heard about the Age tapes that this material is going to contain evidence that would go to prove that individuals have been guilty of very serious criminal offences such as, for example, conspiracy to commit a murder. The Attorney-General wants that evidence to be available before the courts. As I understand what he said in his second reading speech and as I understand the Bill, that is the intent, so that a real use can be made of the material. But the point that I put to him-it is not a hypothetical point-is that we all know that people involved in organised crime have a lot of money and with a split High Court on such an important question it is very likely, so it seems to me, that the High Court is going to be asked to review its decision. If Mr Justice Murphy is not able to sit, and say it is a six-man High Court, the result will be that the opinion of the Chief Justice will prevail. I feel rather as though I was at Custer's last stand when instead of the Red Indians turning up the cavalry has arrived with reinforcements. But, if we are to make sure that a seven-man High Court cannot overturn the decision which has already been given, the only way we can do it is by amending the Act. I move:
Clause 4, page 3, at the end of proposed section 7BA, add the following sub-section:

'(6) Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Act, but subject otherwise to the rules as to admissibility of evidence, documents or information or oral evidence of interceptions falling within sub-section (1) may be admitted as evidence in criminal proceedings.'.

That is what the Attorney seeks to achieve, so why does he not put it beyond doubt? That is all I ask. I would put the matter beyond doubt. I do not want to say anything further upon the subject. TALK.START.PARA: —My object in participating in this debate is to make a contribution towards redressing the balance of political debate in Australia and to combat the propaganda of the proponents of free-market ideology. This ideology is increasingly permeating conservative Liberal and National Party decision-making throughout Australia and is traditionally associated with the rhetoric-we will get to the National Party in a minute-but not the practice of the conservative parties in Australia. That conservative ideology has as its basic premise the economic law of the jungle, the survival of the fittest. Thus, if individuals in society end up living in poverty or on the unemployment scrap-heap, the conservatives say it is that individual's fault. I believe that this is a dangerous and unjust creed to preach and one which has clearly as its end target an attack on the public sector and government expenditure which, in turn, is a crucial factor in determining the quality of life of all Australians. The public sector is not only a support to it is an-
—You have been reading too many books.

—It is an affliction that the honourable member for Franklin will never suffer from. The public sector is not only a support to and a condition necessary for the development of the Australian economy; its activities are also necessary for the personal development and freedom of the Australian people. Those who condone an inefficient and bureaucratic public sector will get no support from me because I regard it as essential that the public sector be a pace-setter in efficient administrative practices and public accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: In the current debate on taxation reform the views of the so-called Liberal Party dries are increasingly reflected in the public comments of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) who, as we all know, has to pander to that section of the Party to maintain his tenuous hold on the Liberal Party leadership. The views of those members of the Liberal and National parties assert that the overall level of taxation in Australia is too high and, related to that, that the size of the public sector in Australia is too large and has also to be reduced. They are the exponents and champions of the elitist creed which is best described in the phrase 'private affluence and public squalor'. Both the assertions they promote have no basis in fact and are clever emotive tools of those hard line free market theorists in the Liberal Party who are attempting to build public support for their ideology.

To lay the first point to rest, when a comparison is made between Australia and other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, it can be readily seen that Australia is not amongst the highest taxed countries. In fact, the exact opposite is true. The taxation level in Australia falls well below the OECD average. The last comprehensive OECD survey of trends in tax levels showed that while total tax receipts in Australia rose from 22.6 per cent of GDP in 1955 to 30.8 per cent in 1980 it was a much lower increase than was evident in other Western industrialised countries. We are still below the OECD average for 1980 of 35.8 per cent. In case that is not clear to honourable members opposite, let me spell it out. Those people who claim that the size of the taxation cake in Australia is too high do not tell the people of Australia that the following countries had a higher overall level of taxation expressed as a percentage of GDP than Australia in the last year for which figures are available: Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden and the United Kingdom. All those countries had a lower overall tax level than Australia.

I particularly wish to highlight the fact that although the overall level of taxation in Australia is lower than in most OECD countries, the proportion collected through personal income taxes is considerably higher. The problem is not that the overall level of taxation is too high but that those who can least afford it have been hardest hit by the tax slug. Whereas individuals paid 32.9 per cent of total tax receipts in 1955, rising to 44.3 per cent in 1979, the share paid by corporations fell from 15.9 per cent in 1959 to only 10.3 per cent in 1979. Thus by world standards Australia collects a very high proportion of its total revenue from personal income tax. On a comparative basis, of the OECD countries Australia has the second highest proportion of overall income taxes to total taxes. This unjust tax burden on the average Australian wage and salary earner and on families, including families in my electorate of Hughes, is something that this Government is determined to correct; something that honourable members opposite did nothing about over all their sorry decades in government.

The present taxation system represents an intolerable and grossly unfair state of affairs. The richest sector of the economy is paying proportionately less of the overall tax burden while the majority-the lower and middle income earners-are expected by the Liberal and National parties to pay proportionally more. We reject that creed. Behind all of this Liberal Party ethos lies the scandal of the tax avoidance industry. It thrived under the previous Government and still the Opposition seeks to protect it.

Mr Speaker, I return to the central thrust of my contribution. I condemn the free market advocacy of a reduced public sector. It is appropriate to examine in this regard Australia's level of government outlays as a proportion of GDP as compared to OECD countries. That is what we do not see the conservatives doing.

—Not only do I and the Government deplore, but I believe the overwhelmingly majority of the Australian people deplore, the way in which this question was asked. One would have thought, as I have had cause to say before in this place, that the statements of the President of the United States of America, the Secretary of State of the United States, and all other spokesmen for the United States Administration, would have been statements that would have been accepted by those opposite. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted, the facts are that when I was in Washington at the beginning of last month I was able to sit down with President Reagan, Secretary of State Shultz, Secretary of Defense Weinberger, their advisers and my own and have an entirely rational discussion about this issue in which I put without equivocation the clear position of the Australian Government. I was able to say to the President that we in no way questioned the integrity of his approach and the approach of the United States Administration.

ANSWER.PARA: In saying that, let me parenthetically observe that I repudiate any of this propagandist assertion that may come from some quarters that what the United States Government is about is to create a situation in which it would be able to utilise a first strike capacity. I completely repudiate that as propagandist nonsense.

We were able, calmly and rationally, to discuss that with the President of the United States and his advisers. We did it rationally and in a way in which our arguments were listened to. While they would not have been embraced, they were accepted by the President and his advisers as positions put in good faith by the Prime Minister of this country on behalf of the Government and the people of this country.

I simply say that it is a great tragedy that when the President and his advisers are able to accept the position of this Government as one being put in good faith, the Opposition of this country cannot do the same thing.

The fact is that there are men and women of goodwill within the conservative spectrum of politics in the United States, as there are among the allies of the United States, who do not embrace the SDI initiative. I do not think, for instance, that Sir Geoffrey Howe of the United Kingdom Government would in the lexicon of politics be put down as a raving left wing lunatic. Nevertheless, Sir Geoffrey Howe has expressed his reservations about the SDI program.

In other words, at the same time as one can accept the integrity with which the President and the Administration of the United States approach this issue, which I and the Government accept, it is possible to entertain serious doubts as I and my Government and many people on the conservative side of politics within the United States and in conservative parties around the world have.

In other words, one is dealing with an issue of the most fundamental importance. This is not some miserable partisan issue. One is dealing with questions which go to the very issue of whether this world will be able to survive the great danger of a nuclear holocaust and whether in fact men and women will be able to survive in the future on this planet. This is the nature of the issue which is involved here. It becomes people in politics in this country and elsewhere to approach this issue not only with the seriousness that it deserves but also with the seriousness which the United States Administration itself displays in being prepared to allow any discussions with others.

Let me make it quite clear that we have put our position to the United States Administration. The integrity of this Government has been accepted. I remind those on the other side of the House that it was after I had discussions with the President and his advisers and put the Government's position on that issue that the President issued the statement he did which put properly the relationship between the United States and the Government of this country at the highest possible level. In other words, having heard our position on this issue he reiterated his conviction on the importance and the enduring strength of our alliance relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Prime Minister that the Soviet Union walked out of the Geneva disarmament talks in November of 1983 because of the proposed deployment of Pershing and cruise missiles in Western Europe and, moreover, that the Soviet Union subsequently demanded that the United States of America withdraw its missiles or agree in advance to do so as a condition for reopening negotiations. In light of the fact that disarmament negotiations have now resumed in Geneva, despite the Soviet demands not being met, will the Prime Minister advise the House whether a major factor in the Soviet Union's resumption of these disarmament talks was its reaction to the strategic defence initiative?

—It is the case that many analysts believe that the initiative of the United States Administration in this area was a factor in the decision of the Soviet Union to agree to a resumption of the talks. It would be quite futile to deny that obvious fact. As to what weight is to be given to that element, there is no one here or elsewhere who can be definitive about it. But I would not attempt in any way to ignore that this initiative is put as one of the elements. If we proceed from that to what would seem to be the logic of what the Leader of the Opposition is getting at, let us look at more recent events. Honourable members would have noticed that in the United States this week the President of the United States had a very tough battle to get passage, first in the Senate and latterly in the House of Representatives, of legislation in regard to the MX missile. It is very interesting that in his successful attempt to get the numbers in respect of his position on the MX missile issue, he brought the chief negotiator back from Geneva. The facts are that in the House of Representatives there was a margin, as I recall, of about six votes. Part of the argument put by the President and those supporting him was that the position of the United States should not be prejudiced in the negotiations in Geneva. Is it being suggested by the Leader of the Opposition and other honourable members opposite that nearly half of the members of the House of Representatives in the Congress are treacherous and are traitors to the interests of the US because they rejected the argument of the President and of the chief negotiator? Are honourable members opposite suggesting that those who did not vote for the President were prejudicing the interests of the United States?
—No one mentioned traitors.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—You are attacking the minority because it is easier.

—I think I should offer a general warning that I will not just keep asking honourable members to cease interjecting. The level of interjection is getting quite ridiculous. As a matter of fact, it is in accord with some of the letters I receive from listeners who say Question Time should be cut out of the broadcasts.

—The logic of the position of the Leader of the Opposition and honourable members opposite means that approximately half of the representatives in the Congress of the United States are treacherous and are traitors because they would not accept an argument in regard to the MX missile. I do not accept the proposition that half the members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives in the United States Congress are traitors and are treacherous because they, with integrity, have a different view on this issue. I repeat that the nature of the issues we are talking about here are of such profound importance that men and women of good will, with total integrity, can have a different point of view. The interests of rational discussion and the salvation of men and women and their future on this planet are not served by the simplistic proposition that unless we embrace one doctrine we are traitors and are treacherous to the cause of peace and international understanding. Once we get to that position, we will have guaranteed the end of rational constructive debate. I repeat that, just as in the United States half of the members of the United States Congress are not to be labelled as traitors and treacherous because they will not embrace a particular argument, in this country and in all other democracies those who do not happen to share a particular doctrine do not deserve to be labelled as traitors. They deserve to have their views taken as being advanced by people of integrity.

PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
National Flag
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The proposed work is for the provision of further shipbuilding facilities at Williamstown dockyard necessary for the construction of two vessels under the Australian frigate project, and to improve the general efficiency of the dockyard. The work proposed under this submission comprises support service centre; occupational health centre; guided missile launcher system assembly building; upgrading of existing workshops and canteen; shipbuilding platens II; mobile plant facility; administration building annexe; car parking; shallow pits in Alfred graving dock; security measures; and site works and engineering services.

The proposed work was previously referred to the Committee in September 1984 but the Committee was unable to undertake any inquiries and table a report before the dissolution of the House in October. The reference therefore lapsed. Now that the new Committee has been formed the Government desires that the proposal be again referred for consideration and report.

The estimated cost of the proposal when previously referred to the Committee was $13m at September 1984 prices. The current cost at January 1985 prices is $13.25m.
